The  PRC  economy  grew  rapidly  during  the  past  decade—averaging  around  10%  per 
annum—and  is  expected  to  continue  growing  rapidly  in  the  foreseeable  future.  Despite  this 
good progress, the Government’s fight against poverty is far from over. There is a need to raise 
the living standards of millions of people, particularly in the western region. The inadequate road 
network,  road  transport  bottlenecks,  and  the  resulting  high  transport  costs  and  poor  levels  of 
service are core constraints to achieving key economic and social development objectives. 
 
The  economy’s  changing  structure  has  altered  the  pattern  of  transport  demand.  
3. 
The network of 1.8 million kilometers (km) of roads at the end of 2003, was longer by 44,600 km 
from 2002. The motor vehicle fleet is growing at 15–30% per annum. In 2003 the vehicle fleet 
consisted  of  about  24.3  million  trucks,  cars,  and  buses;  and  72.3  million  other  motorized 
vehicles, mainly motorcycles and agricultural vehicles. In 1985–2003 the privately owned fleet of 
motor  vehicles  increased  more  than  40  times,  from  300,000  vehicles  to  12.5  million.  In  2003, 
road passenger volume and passenger-km accounted for about 92.3% and 55.7%, respectively, 
of all modes. Despite its rapid increase over recent years, the motorization rate is lower than in 
many other Asian and Pacific countries, with only 1.3 vehicles (trucks, cars, or buses) for every 
100 persons.1 Given the PRC's rapid economic growth, low vehicle ownership rates, lower car 
prices as tariff barriers fell after accession to the World Trade Organization, steadily increasing 
incomes,  increasing  access  to  loans  to  finance  automobile  purchases,  and  investment  in 
automotive  manufacturing  ($6  billion  provided  by  state  banks  during  2001–2003),  the  vehicle 
fleet  is  anticipated  to  grow  rapidly  in  the  coming  years.  The  Asian  Develoment  Bank  (ADB)  is 
supporting the improvements of road transport efficiency in the PRC.2

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

 

6. 
Despite  the  huge  amount  of  investment,  PRC’s  road  network  has  weaknesses  that  are 
particularly evident in the poor rural areas  of the western region (Supplementary Appendix A). 
High-standard  expressways  account  for  only  1.6%  of  the  total  network,  while  class  I  roads 
represent 1.7%, and class II 11.8%. About 70% of the county and township roads are gravel or 
earth  roads.  In  total,  173  townships  and  56,693  villages  have  no  road  connections.  No  public 
transport services are available in 1,000 townships and 160,000 villages, most of which are in 
western region. Expressways are built on the outskirts of  key urban  areas,  but  connections  to 
the  city  center  are  insufficient.  About  85%  of  the  total  network  does  not  have  adequate  traffic 
signals, signs, or markings. Lack of transport integration and high logistics costs, have hindered 
the development of the domestic market.

driving, no speeding, and no unruly driver behavior. The plan also covers emergency and health 
care  services.  Education  will  address  target  road  users,  the  community  and  children  through 
lectures and publicity  materials. Three static advertisements (4  m  x 6  m) to be built under the 
Project  will  be  displayed  by  the  police  in  selected  sites,  together  with  awareness  materials,  to 
maximize safety. This is a new initiative accepted by a police department in the PRC as part of

the project area by an average of 90 deaths per annum over a 15-year period. The loan will also

Economic  Benefits.  The  economic  impacts  of  the  Project  were  analyzed  for  the

increased traffic in the corridor will cause congestion, increase vehicle operating costs (VOCs), 
and reducing road safety and accessibility. The expressway will provide the needed increase in 
capacity.  Economic  benefits  of  traffic  transferring  to  the  expressway  from  the  existing  G324 
include travel time savings, savings in transport costs allowing more efficient transport services, 
and  increases  in  safety  and  comfort.  Environmental  benefits  which  will  also  come  from  the 
reduced  vehicle  emissions  and  noise  were  not  included  in  the  analysis  because  of  a  lack  of 
suitable data and evaluation methodology. GCD will build noise barriers along the expressway 
where  required.  The  lower  transport  costs  will  facilitate  further  economic  growth  in  the  area, 
leading to higher traffic flows and toll revenues. Traffic continuing to use the existing G324 will 
benefit  from  reduced  congestion  and  accidents.  The  expressway's  economic  costs  cover 
construction, land acquisition and resettlement, environmental management, and O&M. For the 
local roads component, benefits arise from (i) the increased per capita incomes in remote areas 
due to lower transport costs and improved access resulting in better agricultural prices, cheaper 
inputs,  and  improved  access  to  markets;  (ii)  savings  in  VOCs;  and  (iii)  increased  personal 
mobility  giving  greater  employment  opportunities  and  allowing  social  interaction  and  improved 
access  to  facilities,  all  of  which  will  help  raise  the  overall  level  of  welfare  of  the  project 
beneficiaries.  With  an  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  of  17.8%,  for  the  combined 
expressway  and  local  roads,  the  Project  is  considered  economically  viable.  The  EIRR  for  the 
expressway component itself is 17.1% and that for the local roads is about 65%. This high figure 
reflects  the  relatively  low  costs  of  the  upgrading  proposed  for  these  roads  and  the  substantial 
benefits  that  are  potentially  achievable  with  improved  accessibility.  Likely  changes  in  the  key 
variables or an assessment of the risks do not significantly affect viability, and in the entire set of 
standard  tests  the  EIRR  remains  well  above  the  12%  threshold  (Appendix  12  and 
Supplementary Appendix I).

proposed  for  other  roads  in  Guangxi.  Given  the  traffic  forecast  and  toll  levels,  the  financial 
performance  of  the  Project  is  satisfactory  (Appendix  13).  To  confirm  the  appropriate  toll  level 
GCD will undertake a toll study before opening the expressway and yearly for 5 years thereafter 
and will submit the results to ADB for comment. The level of the tolls will be designed to ensure 
that  the  revenue  will  cover  O&M  costs,  debt  service,  and  depreciation  in  excess  of  debt 
servicing; and generate an acceptable rate of return on the investment. Financial evaluation was 
undertaken  in  real  terms  using  constant  2004  prices.  The  project  cost  estimates  and  financial 
projections in nominal terms were converted to real terms by adjusting for the projected effects 
of foreign and domestic inflation and currency fluctuation. Incremental costs and benefits were 
derived  by  evaluating  the  financial  position  of  the  GCD  in  with-  and  without-project  scenarios.

7%. This compares favorably with the weighted average cost of capital (WACC) of 2.7%, also 
computed  on  an  after-tax  basis.  The  Project  is  considered  both  financially  viable  and 
sustainable. Sensitivity and risk analysis indicates that the FIRR for the Project overall is robust 
under  adverse  conditions.  The  more  detailed  financial  analysis  is  in  Appendix  14  and 
Supplementary Appendix G.

road, rail, and inland waterway. Each mode plays a different role, with only limited competition

1. 
The  Project  comprises  the  expressway  from  Nanning  (Tanluo)  to  Baise  and  the  local 
road connected to the expressway through the road network system. The main civil works of the 
expressway will be executed in 3 years and the economic analysis covers that period and the 
following 21 years of operation. The expressway’s economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was 
estimated by comparing the situations with and without the new road. Without the Project, the 
existing  road  network  will  become  congested  because  of  rapidly  increasing  traffic  and  some 
trips  will  be  suppressed.  The  Project  will  reduce  congestion;  offer  faster,  cheaper,  and  safer 
travel; and allow additional trip making. The analysis has been undertaken for each component 
of the Project and for the whole Project, using 2003/04 prices. 
 
A. 
 
2. 
the 
construction of the expressway itself and construction of the connecting roads. The costs of the 
expressway include (i) capital costs: physical contingencies, costs of land acquisition, costs of 
environmental  mitigating  measures,  and  compensation  or  relocation  of  affected  people;  and  
(ii) costs of operating and maintaining the expressway. 
 
Benefit.  The  economic  benefits  include  (i)  savings  in  vehicle  operating  costs  (VOCs) 
3. 
resulting  from  shorter  travel  time  and  improved  traffic  conditions,  (ii)  savings  in  the  value  of 
passenger time, (iii) savings resulting from fewer accidents, and (iv) benefits to generated traffic. 
In addition there will be environmental benefits from reduced vehicle emissions and noise, and 
indirect  economic  benefits  resulting  from  increased  in  economic  growth  in  the  corridor 
generated  by  the  new  road.  However,  these  indirect  benefits  were  not  been  included  in  the 
analysis for lack of a suitable evaluation methodology. The main source of economic benefits is 
the  reduced  VOCs.  The  new  road  shortens  the  route  between  Nanning  and  Baise  by  
14 kilometers (kms) and provides better operating conditions. Traffic diverted to the expressway 
will enjoy higher speeds on a smoother road, with better vertical and horizontal alignment, less 
congestion, and a shorter through distance; and will gain substantial benefits. All these changes 
affect  VOCs—which  were  estimated  using 
the  standard  Highway  Development  and 
Management  System  (HDM)  VOC  estimation  techniques—and  the  savings  were  then 
incorporated  into  the  economic  evaluation.  The  other  main  sources  of  economic  benefits  are 
time savings, accident savings and the benefits to generated traffic. The value of time savings 
has  been  determined  based  on  the  reduction  in  journey  times  and  the  value  of  time  of 
passengers traveling in and through the corridor, taking into account the characteristics of these 
travelers. Accident cost savings were based in part on an analysis of national and local accident 
statistics  for  2002.  The  unit  costs  of  accidents  are  based  on  a  review  of  the  severity  of 
accidents, taking into account damage to property and the value of output lost. 
 
4. 
Benefits  to  the  additional  traffic  attracted  to  the  corridor  were  estimated  by  calculating 
the  generalized  cost  savings  for  traffic  using  the  expressway  in  each  forecast  year  and  then 
attributing 50% of this change in costs to the increases in traffic over the level that would exist if 
the expressway was not constructed. The evaluation also accounts for the time taken for the full 
level of demand on the expressway to be achieved, as travelers adjust their travel behavior to 
take advantage of the new opportunities that become available. This is reflected in the analysis 
by assuming that only 50% of the full forecast benefits are achieved in the first year (2008) of 
operation and 85% in the second (2009).

population especially those living in poor isolated areas between the corridor and the Vietnam 
border. The project would also enhance the accessibility of the border areas and help stimulate

2003/04 prices. This part of the Project will upgrade an existing unsealed road and will directly 
serve  a  poor  and  isolated  community.  Quantified  benefits  include  the  changes  in  VOCs  and 
travel times with the new road, accident savings, and benefits to generated traffic. This analysis 
gave  an  EIRR  of  about  17%,  with  a  net  present  value  of  about  CNY90  million.  However  it  is 
likely that substantial benefits are offered by the enhanced mobility and opportunities for cross 
Border activity, but are not captured in the quantified analysis.

2008 onward. International inflation is estimated at 1% in 2004, 1.53% in 2005, 0.89% in 2006

fluctuations using the assumption of purchasing power parity. 
 
B. 
 
2. 
The financial projections include revenues from operating (toll) revenues and other non-
operating  revenues  primarily  from  advertising  and  rental  income  from  operators  of  fueling 
stations and other services available in the service areas along the expressway. Based on past 
experiences  of  existing  expressways  in  Guangxi  Zhuang  Autonomous  Region  (Guangxi),  the 
net  revenues  from  these  other  activities  are  estimated  at  1  percent  of  total  toll  revenues 
collected. 
 
3. 
Operating revenues from tolls are projected based on forecast traffic and a base toll rate 
of  CNY0.35  per  passenger  car  per  kilometer  (km).  Corresponding  tolls  for  other  vehicle  types 
are CNY0.35 for a small truck, CNY0.81 for a bus, CNY0.81 for a medium truck, CNY1.97 for a 
large truck, and CNY1.97 for a trailer and container truck. The assumed toll rate is forecast to 
increase every 5 years in normal terms from the opening of the expressway to keep up with the 
inflation  rate  (16%  over  5  years,  or  an  average  of  3%  per  year).  The  proportion  of  exempted 
vehicles  such  as  police,  ambulance,  and  security  and  inspection  cars  is  estimated  at  6%  of 
passenger cars. 
 
4. 
The  traffic  volume  is  sensitive  to  the  toll  level.  The  diversion  of  traffic  according  to  a 
change  of  toll  rates  is  estimated  based  on  the  Toll  Diversion  Model  Application  Manual 
(September 2000) developed by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and reflected in the traffic 
forecast for the Project.  
 
During the 1–2 years of opening a new expressway, not all forecast traffic will appear on 
5. 
the expressway. To reflect this, a “ramp-up” factor of 50% of forecast traffic is estimated for the 
first year of operation (2008) and 85% in the second year (2009).

exempted  during  the  first  2  years  of  operation,  but  will  gradually  be  increased  to  15%  of  net 
profit during year 3 to year 5. From year 6, a standard 33% will be applied to the corporation.

The  pro  forma  financial  statements  (Appendix  14)  show  that  although  the  expressway

13.  Major assumptions used for calculating the financial internal rate of return (FIRR) are as 
follows:  (i)  all  calculations  are  in  2004  constant  prices,  covering  the  period  from  2005–2028;  
(ii)  capital  costs  consist  of  all  capital  expenditures  related  to  the  construction  and  equipment 
associated  with  the  Project,  but  excludes  price  contingencies  and  financial  charges  during 
construction; (iii) operating revenues from toll used in financial projections are adjusted to 2004 
real terms; (iv) incremental O&M costs are also adjusted to 2004 real terms; (v) residual value of 
the assets is computed based on the average economic asset life for different items. 
 
14. 
The  level  of  the  proposed  toll  rates  shown  in  the  base  case  of  the  financial  and 
economic  evaluations  gives  financial  and  economic  results  that  are  well  within  the  range  of 
acceptability. We have tested a range of toll rates and the impact on the FIRR and the economic 
internal rate of return (EIRR) and plotted these relationships on a graph (Figure A13). The graph 
shows  that  at  100%  of  the  base  toll  rate,  the  after-tax  FIRR  is  just  bout  7%  and  the  EIRR  is 
approximately  17%.  At  higher  toll  rates,  the  EIRR  declines  to  12%  at  between  1.5  and  1.6 
multiplier level of the base toll. The FIRR increases slightly at the toll multiplier level of 1.25, and 
then  declines  at  higher  multipliers.  At  lower  toll  rates,  the  FIRR  declines  and  approaches  the 
weighted average cost of capital (WACC) at about the toll multiplier of 0.5. We consider that the

B.  Poverty Analysis  
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
Of the 17 project counties, 16 are either national or provincial poor counties in the project area (PA). The causes of 
poverty  in  the  PA  are  lack  of  access  to  outside  markets  and  unemployment  due  to  remoteness  and  isolation. 
Insufficient  infrastructure  (e.g.,  roads)  and  an  unfavorable  environment  (e.g.,  being  drought  prone  in  stony 
mountainous  areas)  worsen  the  poverty  situation.  Rural  poverty  in  the  PA,  measured  as  per  capita  income  below 
CNY900, affects 2.3 million people (46% of the rural population). Absolute poverty (<CNY625) affects a population of 
0.57 million (12%). Food security has generally been achieved due to favorable climatic conditions and technical and 
infrastructure progress in agriculture. Some mountain communities, however, might suffer from food shortage once in 
several years in case of natural disaster. The urban poor (<CNY130/capita/month) is about 60,000 (9.5%) of the total 
urban  population.  About  823,000  rural  and  urban  poor—accounting  for  34%  of  the  total  beneficiaries—will  directly 
benefit  from  the  Project.  About  39%  of  the  beneficiaries  in  the  PA  are  the  rural  poor.  The  Project  itself  will  directly 
generate economic opportunities for the poor through improved access to urban markets and to other social services, 
reduced transport costs, and better access to and interaction with other regions, including labor migration. Directly and 
indirectly, through the promotion of agricultural commercialization and of local level urbanization, the Project will help 
amplify the effects of ongoing poverty reduction efforts. In addition, the Project will promote the development of local 
tourism  in  remote  and  isolated  areas.  With  the  employment  opportunities  created,  increased  agricultural  and 
nonagricultural activities, and rise in labor migration, the poor’s annual income per capita is estimated to increase 11% 
annually for 2004–2014.
